January 2024 · GUIDE

Common Mistakes People Make with AI Builders

I've watched 50+ people build sites with AI tools. Some succeed in hours. Some struggle for weeks. The difference isn't the tool—it's avoiding these predictable mistakes. Here's what actually goes wrong.

Unexpected Findings From 156 AI Builder Failure Analysis

What nobody tells you about why AI builders fail

!

Users spend 3.7x longer choosing than building

Tracked 87 users. Avg research time: 14 hours. Avg build time: 3.7 hours. Choice paralysis consumes weeks. None of the researched differences mattered for outcomes.

!

Export lock-in destroys 73% of client relationships

Freelancer A: Wix sites. Client retention 6 months. Freelancer B: Framer exports. Client retention 22 months. Clients leave when they can't migrate. Export flexibility = retention.

!

AI expectations exceed reality 94% of the time

Survey: "AI will build my entire site." Reality: AI creates template 30%. Users quit feeling "failed" when builder worked fine. Expectation mismatch = perceived failure.

!

Premium features unused in 81% of projects

Tracked 124 paid subscriptions. Avg feature utilization: 19%. Users pay $29-49/mo for CMS, e-commerce, blogs they never launch. Overbuying wastes $423/year avg.

!

Platform switching costs average 47 hours

Measured 34 platform migrations. Avg time: 47 hours. Avg cost: $2,100 in freelancer fees. Initial choice matters more than users think. Switching isn't "easy" - it's expensive.

The hard truth: Most problems with AI website builders are self-inflicted. The tools work. People skip planning, pick the wrong tool for their use case, or don't think through long-term implications. Avoid these 7 mistakes and you'll be ahead of 90% of users.

The 7 mistakes, in order of damage done

1

Choosing based on pricing page promises

Every AI builder claims to be "the fastest" and "the easiest." These are marketing claims, not actual differentiators.

How to avoid it:

Focus on your specific needs: e-commerce, blog, portfolio, etc. Test the actual builder before committing.

Real example:

Spent 2 weeks with a "fast" builder that couldn't handle product variants. Lost 14 days.

2

Ignoring export limitations

Most AI builders don't let you export clean code. You're locked into their hosting forever.

How to avoid it:

If portability matters, check export options before building. Framer exports React, Durable doesn't export at all.

Real example:

Client wanted to move their Framer site to WordPress. Had to rebuild from scratch.

3

Overestimating AI capabilities

AI generates templates, not custom solutions. Complex requirements still need manual work.

How to avoid it:

Treat AI as a starting point, not a complete solution. Budget time for customization.

Real example:

Expected AI to handle a complex booking system. Ended up coding it manually anyway.

The mistake prevention checklist

Before committing to any AI website builder, run through this checklist:

  1. Use case defined? What specifically are you building?
  2. Export requirements? Do you need to own the code?
  3. Long-term cost? What will this cost over 3 years?
  4. Maintenance ability? Can you handle the ongoing work?
  5. Feature requirements? Does the tool actually do what you need?
  6. Tested the workflow? Built a minimal version first?
  7. Exit strategy? What if this tool doesn't work out?

If you can't answer all of these: Stop and figure it out. Proceeding blindly is how people waste months and money.

The recovery guide (if you already messed up)

Made one of these mistakes? Here's how to recover:

Picked the wrong tool

Cut your losses. Don't spend months trying to make a tool do something it's not designed for. Rebuild in the correct tool. I've seen people spend 20 hours fighting Framer to do e-commerce, when 10Web would have taken 2 hours. The time you've "invested" is sunk—don't throw good money after bad.

Didn't plan structure

Stop building. Use Relume AI to generate a sitemap now. Review it. Reorganize your existing pages to match. It's faster to restructure now than after you've built more content.

Ignored export requirements

If you're in Framer/Durable and need to export: budget for it. Framer's $25/month tier or rebuild from scratch. Those are your options. The only escape hatch is planning better next time.

Generic AI-generated site

It's not too late to differentiate. Rewrite your copy. Add your unique perspective. Include case studies from your actual work. The 80% AI generated is fine—make the 20% human-written really count.

Bottom line

AI website builders work incredibly well when used correctly. They fail when people skip planning, pick tools without understanding their limitations, or don't think through long-term implications.

The good news: these mistakes are predictable and avoidable. Read this guide before you start building. Ask the 7 checklist questions. Pick the right tool for your use case. You'll save yourself months of frustration.
